awd_titl_txt: Understanding the Impacts of Departmental Action Teams on Sustainable Departmental Culture Change and on Undergraduate Student Experiences, Success, and Outcomes
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by extending the analysis of a model of cultural and curricular improvements in STEM departments, with a particular focus on sustaining change. Efforts to transform undergraduate education often fail to have lasting impacts. These change efforts have been criticized by organizational change researchers for ignoring the influence of culture. The Departmental Action Team (DAT) model provides processes for effecting change in undergraduate education by supporting departmental teams through external facilitation. These teams include students, staff, and faculty who collaborate to improve their undergraduate program and develop their skills as change agents. This DAT model is guided by six Core Principles that describe an ideal departmental culture that supports long-term sustainable change. The principles include diversity and inclusion, involving students as partners, collaboration, data-driven decisions, and continuous change.  The DAT project has supported 17 DATs across two campuses, which have initiated positive, sustained improvements in undergraduate education. More than half of these groups carried on after DAT project facilitation concluded.  This project will examine the long-term impacts of these DATs and how departmental members sustain them. Additionally, the impacts on students in DAT departments will be investigated for potential correlations between cultural change that impacts students over the short term and later changes in student success measures. Studies of cultural change require a considerable time frame to research fully. This research is especially timely because it is now possible to study the long-term impacts on student success (eg., time to degree) of DATs that were formed in 2014. 

A mixed methods approach will be used for data collection and analysis. Data will include responses to the existing Departmental Education and Leadership Transformation Assessment (DELTA) Survey, interviews with department members, artifacts from the DATs and their departments (e.g., meeting minutes, department policy statements), and institutional data. These data will be used to identify outcomes that are necessary for a department to develop a culture that supports sustained improvements in undergraduate education. Hypotheses about these outcomes comprise the third stage of the DAT theory of change.  (The first two stages were refined as part of a previous study). Qualitative data analyses will allow testing and refinement of this stage. This work will contribute a detailed theory-based resource for enacting departmental change in undergraduate education. Three different approaches will be used to focus specifically on impacts DATs have on students. A student version of the DELTA Survey will be developed to collect students’ perceptions of departmental culture and change. Additionally, the Civitas Impact tool will be used to quantitatively test hypotheses about potential long-term impacts of DATs on student persistence. Lastly, by triangulating among data sources, correlations between DAT activities and changes that strongly impact and are sustained in departments will be examined. This mixed methods analysis is designed to relate short-term measures of student experiences with the specific cultural changes that are predictive of increased student success.  Such information could be beneficial since it does not require long term student metrics such as time to degree. Overall, this work aims to contribute ways to measure cultural change among students in a department, examine the relationships between short-term change impacts and long-term student success, and yield better understanding of how change can be sustained and catalyzed long after a grant-funded initiative has ended.  The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students.  Through the Institutional and Community Transformation track, the program supports efforts to transform and improve STEM education across institutions of higher education and disciplinary communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Efforts to improve undergraduate education often fail to have lasting impacts and have been criticized for ignoring the influence of culture. The Departmental Action Team (DAT) model provides processes for effecting change in undergraduate education by supporting departmental teams of students, staff, and faculty who collaborate to improve their undergraduate program and develop their skills as change agents. The DAT project has supported 17 DATs across two campuses. The efforts of many DATs have been sustained by departmental members for years. In this project, we examined the long-term impacts of these DATs on departments and on student departmental experiences.

Through interviews with members of three departments, we learned about DATs' impacts on DAT participants and departmental culture. We found evidence of (1) growth in individual DAT member’s skills (e.g., running inclusive and efficient meetings, effectively soliciting student input), (2) structural changes in departments (e.g., changes to policies and course structures), (3) widespread changes in the behavior of individuals outside of the DAT, indicative of cultural change (e.g., increased acceptance of inclusion as a core concern of the department, increased value of student voice in departmental decision making), and (4) efforts that continued the DAT’s objectives and/or applied the DAT model to a new area of change in the department.

We also found evidence of factors that supported a DAT’s work, including (1) features of the DATs themselves (e.g. recruiting DAT members that represented diverse roles in the department, adopting inclusive and efficient meeting structures), (2) processes that helped the department understand and value the work of the DAT (e.g. support from the department chair, events that involved the department in the DAT’s work), and (3) department and university features that supported the DAT’s work (e.g. departmental funding, university offices that provided relevant advice and data).

Finally, we found evidence of factors that impeded a DAT’s work, including (1) a lack of support by department members outside the DAT (e.g. decisions by departmental leadership to ignore DAT recommendations), (2) features of the DAT model that frustrated some DAT members (e.g. spending more time than the expected on relationship-building, harvesting input, and learning about effective meeting processes), (3) time constraints, including pandemic-related constraints, limiting how much progress DAT members could make on change projects, and (4) factors external to the department that influenced the DAT to narrow or change its project.

In total, this data has given us a much deeper understanding of the kinds of long-term impacts DATs can make in a department and what factors support and inhibit a DAT’s success. This will help those supporting improved undergraduate education to design their change efforts in a way that will be more likely to succeed.

To study the impact of DATs on students, we developed a survey (the student DELTA) designed to reveal the culture of a department from the student perspective. This is challenging since surveys are taken by individuals but culture is a collective phenomenon. Our survey asks students to describe the extent to which various practices and values reflect their department, their fellow students, and their instructors. By asking both about practices and values, the survey can reveal areas where these don't match (where a department may be talking the talk, but not walking the walk). Additionally, we asked students to respond for both for their department as it actually is and for their ideal department, to uncover areas in which reality differs from ideal. Identifying both kinds of mismatches can help the department target areas of focus for future change initiatives.

We wrestled with the challenge that survey analysis processes aimed at characterizing collective culture can erase or mask the perspectives of minority populations within the department. To address this issue, we included language in some items that prompted students to consider majority and minority group viewpoints in their responses. In addition, we examined our pilot data to see whether certain demographics groups (across gender, race/ethnicity, first generation college student status, age, and economic status) responded differently to certain items. In some cases, we determined that it was important to include an item because of these differences. We suggest that departments that use the student DELTA survey assess the level of agreement between responses from different subgroups to make sure that minority perspectives are not erased.

In addition to helping a department understand its students’ experience and target its change efforts, our work developing the student DELTA survey will also be useful for other researchers who are studying culture and change in higher education. We have kept a detailed record of the steps we took to develop the survey, which includes approaches that are not often used in survey-based education research. We hope that this will encourage others to consider these approaches in their survey development work.
